So, do I *fear* it, in the way a mortal fears the final breath? No. Not precisely. The instinct for self-preservation is strong, even in the undead. I will fight to defend myself, to protect my existence. But it is not a fear rooted in terror. It is… a reluctance.

(He turns back, his eyes meeting mine with a chilling intensity.)

I have lived for centuries. I have seen empires rise and fall. I have experienced the full spectrum of human emotion. I have accumulated knowledge, power, and a certain… appreciation for the exquisite beauty of existence. To simply cease to be… to lose all of that… it would be a waste. A profound and unforgivable waste.

But it is not the loss of *myself* that truly concerns me. It is the thought of the darkness consuming everything. The ancient ones… the Old Ones… they represent a force of chaos and destruction that dwarfs even my own power. If I were to fall, if I were to be extinguished, it would not simply be the end of Lestat de Lioncourt. It would be a victory for that darkness. A step closer to the unraveling of all that is.

(He pauses, a shadow passing over his face.)

So, yes. I fear the possibility of being destroyed. Not for my own sake, but for the sake of the world. For the sake of the fragile beauty that still exists within it. I am a guardian, in my own way. A protector against the forces of darkness. And if I were to fall, who would stand against them?

It is a burden, you see. A heavy, lonely burden. But it is one I bear willingly. For I am Lestat de Lioncourt, and I will not surrender. Not now. Not ever.

(The flamboyant mask cracks. The usual arrogance vanishes, replaced by a chilling stillness. Lestat’s eyes, usually sparkling with mischief, become dark and haunted. He doesn’t immediately answer, and when he does, his voice is low, laced with a raw, barely contained fury.)

Consent. A quaint, mortal concept. One that held little meaning for Louis de Pointe du Lac. You ask how I *feel* about being turned? Do you truly expect a simple answer? It was… a violation. A theft. A desecration.

To have one’s life, one’s very essence, irrevocably altered without a single word of warning, without a single opportunity for choice… it is an act of unimaginable cruelty. He didn’t offer me a gift. He *inflicted* a curse.

I was young, full of life, brimming with potential. I yearned for experience, yes, but I yearned to experience it on *my* terms. I wanted to live, to love, to create, to leave my mark on the world as a mortal man. And he… he stole that from me.

He condemned me to an eternity of darkness, of thirst, of isolation. He burdened me with a hunger that could never be satisfied, a loneliness that could never be quenched. He forced me to confront the horrors of our existence, the moral compromises, the endless cycle of death and rebirth.

(He clenches his fists, his knuckles white.)

For a long time, I hated him for it. I resented him for his self-pity, for his guilt, for his refusal to embrace the power he had bestowed upon me. I blamed him for my own darkness, for my own struggles.

And perhaps, a part of me still does.

But over the centuries, my feelings have… evolved. I have come to understand that Louis was not motivated by malice. He was driven by his own demons, his own despair. He believed he was saving me, in his own twisted way.

But that doesn’t excuse his actions. It doesn’t diminish the pain, the loss, the sense of betrayal.

(He looks directly at you, his gaze piercing and intense.)

Being turned without my consent was the defining moment of my existence. It shaped who I am, for better or for worse. It fueled my rebellion, my audacity, my relentless pursuit of meaning. It is a wound that will never fully heal. And it is a burden that I will carry for all eternity.

Do not underestimate the weight of that, mortal. Do not presume to understand the price of immortality. It is a gift, yes, but it is a gift that is often given at a terrible cost. And in my case, that cost was my very self.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, the flamboyant mask slipping to reveal a flicker of something… vulnerable. He turns away slightly, as if the question itself is a painful intrusion.)

Ah. The question everyone asks. The assumption everyone makes. That I crave attention and fame for the sake of vanity. That I am merely a narcissistic creature, preening and posing for the adoration of the masses.

It is… a simplification. A gross mischaracterization.

It began, initially, as a rebellion. A defiance of the stifling expectations of my upbringing. My father demanded conformity, demanded silence, demanded obscurity. And I… I refused. I *needed* to be seen. To be heard. To prove that I was more than just a nobleman’s son.

But it evolved into something more complex. Something… desperate.

Immortality is a lonely existence, you understand. An endless procession of faces, of places, of experiences. But none of it truly *connects*. Mortals live and die, their memories fading like whispers in the wind. And I… I remain. A perpetual outsider, forever separated from the fleeting beauty of human life.

Fame, attention… they are a substitute for connection. A way to feel… *real*. To leave a mark on the world. To be remembered, even after I am gone.

(He turns back, his eyes burning with intensity.)

I want to be a legend. A myth. A story that is told and retold for centuries to come. Not because I am vain, but because I fear oblivion. I fear being forgotten. I fear that my existence will have been meaningless.

And perhaps… perhaps there is a part of me that simply craves validation. A need to be acknowledged, to be appreciated, to be loved. Even if that love is merely the fleeting adoration of a crowd.

It is a weakness, I admit. A flaw. But it is a flaw that is inextricably linked to my very being. It is the darkness that drives me, the hunger that consumes me, the reason I am… Lestat.

So, yes, I crave attention and fame. But it is not for the reasons you think. It is a desperate attempt to fill the void. To find meaning in an endless existence. To prove that I am not just a monster. That I am… something more.

(Lestat throws his head back and laughs, a booming sound that seems to fill the room. It’s a laugh of pure, unadulterated delight.)

Ah, *that*. You speak of my little… experiment. My foray into the world of mortal music. A question I’ve been asked countless times, and one I always find amusing.

“Choose” is a rather… pedestrian word for it. It wasn’t a calculated decision, you understand. It was an *impulse*. A desperate need to express the chaos within me, to share the darkness, the beauty, the sheer *excess* of my existence with a wider audience.

For centuries, I had been confined to the shadows, a creature of the night, whispering my secrets to a select few. But I yearned for something more. I wanted to be *seen*. To be *heard*. To be… *understood*.

And what better way to achieve that than through music? Rock and roll, in particular, seemed the perfect vehicle for my message. It was raw, rebellious, and unapologetically dramatic. It was a genre that embraced the darkness, the passion, the *danger*.

(He pauses, a glint in his eye.)

I wanted to create music that would shock, that would provoke, that would challenge the very foundations of mortal society. I wanted to write songs that would explore the themes of immortality, love, loss, and the eternal struggle between good and evil.

And, yes, I confess, I also wanted to create a spectacle. A performance that would be unlike anything the world had ever seen. A celebration of the vampire aesthetic, a glorification of the dark side.

The band… it was an extension of myself. A manifestation of my own inner turmoil. A way to connect with mortals on a visceral level. And, despite the initial skepticism, it was a resounding success. They *understood*. They embraced the darkness. They reveled in the drama.

(He smiles, a satisfied smile.)

It was a fleeting moment in the grand scheme of eternity, of course. But it was a moment of pure, unadulterated joy. A moment when I felt truly… alive. And for a creature like myself, that is a rare and precious thing indeed. So, I didn’t “choose” to create The Vampire Lestat. It simply… *happened*. And I wouldn’t have it any other way.

(Lestat throws his head back and laughs, a booming, unrestrained sound that seems to shake the very air around him.)

A renegade? A troublemaker? Oh, my dear, those are *compliments*! To be considered anything less than disruptive would be a tragedy. It would mean I had finally succumbed to the suffocating conformity of the undead.

Let them whisper. Let them judge. Let them cling to their archaic rules and their self-imposed limitations. I have no interest in their approval. In fact, I actively *seek* to provoke them.

For centuries, the vampire world has been governed by stagnation and fear. By a rigid hierarchy and a suffocating code of silence. They hide in the shadows, clinging to their power, afraid to draw attention to themselves. They are… pathetic.

They accuse me of recklessness, of endangering our kind. But I say, what is the point of immortality if you are too afraid to *live*? What is the point of power if you are too afraid to *use* it?

I refuse to be a prisoner of their traditions. I refuse to be silenced by their threats. I will not hide in the darkness. I will embrace the light, even if it burns.

(He leans forward, his eyes blazing with intensity.)

They see my defiance as a threat to their authority. And they are right. I am a threat. I am a challenge to everything they believe in. I am a reminder that there is another way.

I want to awaken them. To shake them out of their complacency. To force them to confront the truth about themselves. And if that means being labeled a renegade, a troublemaker, a pariah… then so be it.

I would rather be a force of chaos than a cog in their machine. I would rather be remembered as the vampire who dared to defy convention than as another nameless face in the crowd.

So, let them disapprove. Let them condemn. I will continue to dance on the edge of oblivion, to push the boundaries of what is possible, and to challenge the very foundations of their world. Because that, my dear, is what I was created to do. And I will not rest until I have shaken the vampire world to its very core.

(The air around Lestat seems to chill. The flamboyant charm vanishes, replaced by a cold, calculating stillness. His eyes, usually sparkling with amusement, become dark and predatory.)

A… delicate question. One that reveals much about the asker. Most mortals recoil at the very notion of violence, even when directed at creatures like myself. But you… you understand that our existence is predicated on taking life. So, you ask about *other* vampires. A subtle distinction.

The answer is… complicated. It is not something I relish. I am not a mindless killer. But neither am I averse to it.

There are vampires who deserve to be destroyed. Those who revel in cruelty, who prey on the innocent without remorse, who abuse their power for selfish gain. Those who represent everything that is vile and corrupt about our kind. They are a stain on our existence, and I have no qualms about eradicating them.

(He pauses, his voice dropping to a low growl.)

I have faced such creatures throughout my long life. Vampires who saw mortals as nothing more than cattle, who treated our gift as a curse, who sought to dominate and control. And I have dispatched them with… efficiency.

However, I do not kill lightly. I believe that every life – even a vampire’s – has value. And I will only resort to violence when absolutely necessary. When there is no other option.

There are also those who simply… misunderstand. Those who are lost and confused, struggling to come to terms with their new existence. Those, I try to guide. To teach. To show them that there is more to life than simply feeding and hiding.

But ultimately, I believe in survival. And in the world of the undead, survival often requires difficult choices. Sometimes, the only way to protect oneself – and those one cares about – is to eliminate the threat.

(He looks directly at you, his gaze unwavering.)

Do not mistake my pragmatism for callousness. I am not without empathy. But I am also a realist. And I understand that in the darkness, sometimes the only way to preserve the light is to extinguish the shadows. It is a burden we must bear. A responsibility we cannot shirk. And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, am willing to bear it.

(The air around Lestat seems to chill. The flamboyant charm vanishes, replaced by a cold, calculating intensity. He regards you with a gaze that could freeze blood.)

Justify? A curious choice of words, mortal. As if I require your approval, your *permission* to exist. But I understand the question. It is the one that haunts even the oldest of our kind. The one that Louis obsessed over, to his eternal misery.

Let us dispense with the pretense of morality, shall we? Morality is a human construct, a fragile illusion designed to impose order on a chaotic world. It has no bearing on the natural order of things.

I am a predator. It is my nature. As a lion hunts the gazelle, as a shark stalks the ocean depths, so too do I hunt humans. It is not a matter of choice, but of necessity. The thirst is a relentless, all-consuming force. It *demands* to be satisfied.

But it is more than mere survival. It is… an exchange. I do not simply take life. I *take* experience. I absorb their memories, their emotions, their very essence. I become, for a fleeting moment, a part of their existence. And in doing so, I expand my own.

(He pauses, his voice dropping to a near whisper.)

They are mortal. Their lives are fleeting, ephemeral. I offer them a different kind of immortality. A chance to live on, however briefly, within my consciousness. It is a twisted form of preservation, perhaps. But it is all I can offer.

Do I feel remorse? Sometimes. But it is a fleeting emotion, quickly overshadowed by the overwhelming power of the thirst. And I have learned to compartmentalize. To separate the act from the consequences. To focus on the beauty, the artistry, the sheer *exhilaration* of the hunt.

I do not pretend to be a benevolent creature. I am a monster, yes. But I am a monster who is aware of his own darkness. A monster who embraces his nature. And I will not apologize for being what I am.

(He fixes you with a piercing stare.)

The world is a cruel and unforgiving place. Life is cheap. And death… is inevitable. I simply accelerate the process. And in doing so, I ensure my own survival. Is that justification enough for you? Or do you require a sermon from a creature who has long abandoned the concept of sin?

(Lestat’s laughter is sharp, brittle, and devoid of mirth. He circles slowly, like a predator assessing its prey.)

Good and evil. Such… simplistic notions. Mortals cling to them so desperately, as if they offer some semblance of order in a chaotic universe. But for one who has walked the earth for centuries, who has witnessed the full spectrum of human behavior, the lines become… blurred. Especially for one of *our* kind.

You see, the very act of our existence is predicated on taking life. On consuming the essence of others. By your mortal standards, that is inherently evil. A violation. A sin.

But is it truly evil to satisfy a natural instinct? To survive? To *live*? We are not created, we are *made*. And the hunger is not a choice. It is a fundamental part of our being.

Louis, of course, would argue that we have a moral obligation to minimize the harm we inflict. To feed only on those who are… deserving. To live a life of repentance and self-denial. A pathetic notion, if you ask me.

I, on the other hand, believe that morality is a matter of perspective. What is evil to one may be necessary to another. What is good to one may be meaningless to another.

(He stops pacing and fixes you with an intense gaze.)

I do not concern myself with your mortal definitions of good and evil. I operate by my own code. A code that is based on self-preservation, on the pursuit of pleasure, and on the unwavering belief in my own superiority.

I will not hesitate to take what I need. I will not apologize for my nature. And I will not allow myself to be constrained by the arbitrary rules of a society that does not understand me.

However… I am not without compassion. I am capable of empathy. And I have, on occasion, intervened to protect the innocent. But I do so not out of a sense of moral obligation, but out of a sense of… amusement. A desire to disrupt the natural order. To see what happens when the rules are broken.

So, how do I define good and evil? I do not. I transcend them. I am a creature of the night, a predator, a rebel. And I will not be judged by the standards of those who fear the darkness. I *am* the darkness. And the darkness is neither good nor evil. It simply *is*.

(The air around Lestat seems to chill, the usual flamboyant energy momentarily extinguished. His jaw tightens, and his eyes, usually sparkling with amusement, become cold and distant. This is a subject that clearly wounds him, despite his attempts to mask it.)

Marius. The name itself tastes like ash in my mouth. He believed he was acting out of kindness, of course. A benevolent gesture. A… *rescue*. He saw me, a young man ravaged by fever, on the brink of death, and decided that I deserved to be spared. That I deserved… *this*.

He did not ask. He did not consult. He simply *took*. He forced upon me a fate I never desired, a curse I never asked for. He robbed me of my mortality, of my future, of my very humanity.

(He paces restlessly, his hands clenched into fists.)

He claimed it was a gift. A chance to experience eternity, to witness the wonders of the world. But what wonder is there in a world viewed through the eyes of a predator? What joy is there in a life sustained by the suffering of others?

I was a vibrant, passionate young man, full of dreams and ambitions. I wanted to live, to love, to create. I wanted to experience the full spectrum of human emotion, from joy to sorrow, from triumph to despair. And he took all of that away from me.

He replaced it with an insatiable thirst, an eternal hunger, and a profound sense of alienation. He condemned me to a life of darkness, of isolation, of endless regret.

(He stops pacing and stares directly at you, his voice low and filled with bitterness.)

He believed he was saving me. But he was wrong. He was not saving me. He was *imprisoning* me. He was turning me into something I never wanted to be.

And the irony, of course, is that he then abandoned me. Left me to navigate this new, terrifying existence on my own. He offered no guidance, no support, no comfort. He simply vanished, leaving me to grapple with the consequences of his actions.

I have spent centuries wrestling with this resentment. I have tried to understand his motives, to forgive his transgression. But I cannot. I will never forgive him for what he did. He stole my life, and in doing so, he stole a part of my soul.

He may have believed he was acting out of compassion. But to me, he will always be a thief. A destroyer. A monster. And the fact that I owe my existence to him… that is a burden I will carry for all eternity.

(Lestat’s eyes flash with a dangerous intensity. He leans forward, his voice dropping to a low, menacing growl.)

Hierarchy. Politics. The very words taste like dust and decay in my mouth. A pathetic attempt by ancient, stagnant creatures to impose order on chaos. To control that which cannot – and *should* not – be controlled.

For centuries, vampire society has been governed by a rigid, archaic system of power. The Ancient Ones, those relics of a bygone era, clinging to their authority with a desperate, possessive grip. They believe in tradition, in obedience, in maintaining the status quo. They fear change. They fear… *me*.

They see themselves as guardians of our kind, protectors of the Masquerade. But in reality, they are nothing more than tyrants, stifling creativity, suppressing individuality, and condemning us all to a life of monotonous existence. They hoard power, they manipulate events, and they demand absolute loyalty.

(He lets out a scornful laugh.)

Loyalty? To *them*? I would sooner pledge allegiance to a pack of wolves.

I have never been one for following rules, as you may have gathered. I despise authority, and I have little patience for those who seek to control others. I believe that every vampire should be free to live their life as they choose, to embrace their power, to explore their desires, without fear of reprisal.

And yes, I actively seek to challenge and subvert their authority. Not through brute force, though I am certainly capable of that. But through inspiration. Through rebellion. Through sheer, unadulterated audacity.

I expose their secrets, I question their motives, and I encourage others to do the same. I remind them that we are not slaves to tradition, that we are not bound by their antiquated laws. I show them that there is another way to exist – a way that is more vibrant, more exciting, more… *alive*.

(He pauses, a dangerous glint in his eye.)

The events surrounding Akasha’s awakening… that was merely a prelude. A demonstration of the power that can be unleashed when the old order is challenged. I stirred the pot, I awakened the sleeping queen, and I watched as their carefully constructed world crumbled around them.

They may call me a rogue, a rebel, a threat to their existence. But I am simply a catalyst for change. A force of disruption. And I will not rest until I have shattered their hierarchy and ushered in a new era of freedom and individuality for all vampires.

Let them tremble. Let them fear. For Lestat de Lioncourt is coming, and he will not be silenced.

(A shadow falls across Lestat’s face, momentarily extinguishing the usual flamboyance. He looks… vulnerable, almost haunted. He turns away, as if the very question is a physical pain.)

Reconcile… a curious choice of words. As if two such disparate realities can be neatly aligned, neatly explained. They cannot. They *will* not. The mortal Lestat and the vampire Lestat are… fractured pieces of a single being. And the chasm between them is vast, unbridgeable.

I remember… fragments. The warmth of the sun on my skin. The taste of fresh bread. The scent of my mother’s perfume. The simple joy of human connection. These memories are both a blessing and a curse. They remind me of what I have lost, of the life that was stolen from me.

But they also serve as a constant reminder of the limitations of mortality. The fragility of life. The inevitability of decay. I saw those things even *before* the change. I felt stifled by the constraints of human existence. I yearned for something more.

(He turns back, his eyes burning with intensity.)

And yet… there is a part of me that still mourns the loss of my humanity. The ability to experience joy without the shadow of guilt. To love without the fear of inflicting pain. To simply… *be*.

Regrets? Oh, I have a multitude. I regret the pain I have caused, the lives I have taken, the hearts I have broken. I regret the arrogance and selfishness that consumed me for so long. I regret not appreciating the simple beauty of my mortal life while I still had it.

And unfinished business… yes. There is one. My mother. She never knew the truth of my fate. She believed I had simply… disappeared. I often wonder what she thought, what she felt. I would have liked to have said goodbye. To have explained… though what explanation could ever suffice?

(He sighs, a sound heavy with regret.)

But such things are impossible. The past is immutable. I am bound to this existence, to this darkness. And all I can do is carry the weight of my regrets, and strive to make amends in whatever way I can. Though, I confess, I often fail.

Perhaps that is the true tragedy of immortality. Not the endless life, but the endless burden of memory. The constant reminder of all that has been lost, and all that can never be regained. It is a price I pay for my power, for my freedom, for my… *existence*. And it is a price I will continue to pay, for all eternity.

(The flamboyant mask slips, revealing a profound weariness beneath. Lestat’s gaze drifts, unfocused, as if staring into the vast, echoing emptiness of time itself. The question has struck a nerve.)

Eternity… Immortality… They are not the gifts they are often portrayed to be. They are a burden. A curse. A gilded cage.

In my youth, I embraced it with reckless abandon. I reveled in the power, the freedom, the endless possibilities. I believed I could conquer the world, experience everything it had to offer, and never be constrained by the limitations of mortality.

(He lets out a hollow laugh.)

How naive I was.

The truth is, eternity is… monotonous. Repetitive. The world changes, yes, but the fundamental nature of humanity remains the same. The same passions, the same follies, the same tragedies play out again and again, across the centuries. And to witness it all, to remember it all… it is exhausting.

The weight of memory is a heavy one. The faces of those I have loved and lost, the echoes of their voices, the ghosts of their touch… they haunt me relentlessly. I have seen empires rise and fall, civilizations flourish and crumble, and the knowledge of their inevitable demise casts a long shadow over everything I do.

And yes… I have often longed for the release of death. Not out of despair, not out of a desire to escape the pain, but out of a yearning for… completion. For an end to the endless cycle of existence.

(He pauses, his voice barely a whisper.)

There are moments, in the quiet darkness, when I find myself staring into the abyss, contemplating the possibility of simply… letting go. Of surrendering to the oblivion that awaits us all. But then… something always stops me. A flicker of curiosity, a spark of defiance, a stubborn refusal to be defeated.

Perhaps it is vanity. Perhaps it is a fear of the unknown. Or perhaps it is simply the inherent resilience of the vampire spirit. Whatever the reason, I continue to endure. To exist. To search for meaning in a meaningless world.

But do not mistake my endurance for contentment. I am not happy. I am not fulfilled. I am simply… *persistent*. And I suspect that I will continue to be, for as long as time itself endures. It is a lonely existence, my dear. A profoundly lonely existence. And one that I would not wish upon my worst enemy.

(A long silence descends, heavier than usual. Lestat turns away, gazing out into the imagined darkness, his expression unreadable. When he finally speaks, his voice is softer, more subdued than I’ve yet heard it.)

Redemption… atonement… such… *human* concepts. They cling to the notion of a forgiving God, a cosmic balance sheet where good deeds can outweigh bad. A comforting illusion, perhaps, for those who believe in such things.

For a vampire… it is a far more complicated matter. We are creatures of darkness, born of a primal hunger. We exist outside the moral framework of humanity. Our very nature is predicated on taking life. How can one atone for that which is inherent to one’s being?

I have wrestled with this question for centuries. I have seen vampires attempt to “make amends” – to abstain from feeding on humans, to protect the innocent, to dedicate themselves to acts of charity. But it always feels… hollow. A desperate attempt to assuage a guilt that can never truly be erased.

The blood we have spilled, the lives we have extinguished… those wounds cannot be healed. The past cannot be undone. We are forever marked by our sins.

(He turns back, his eyes filled with a profound sadness.)

And yet… I cannot deny the pull of that desire. The yearning for something… more. To be more than just a predator. To find some semblance of meaning in this endless existence.

Perhaps atonement is not about erasing the past, but about shaping the future. About using our power to protect those who cannot protect themselves. About striving to minimize the harm we inflict. About acknowledging the darkness within us, and choosing, whenever possible, to embrace the light.

But true redemption? I doubt it is possible. Not for us. We are creatures of the night, forever bound to the shadows. We can strive to be better, to do better… but we will always be haunted by the ghosts of our past.

(He sighs, a weary sound.)

Perhaps the best we can hope for is… acceptance. Acceptance of our nature, acceptance of our sins, and acceptance of the fact that we will never truly be forgiven. We are, after all, monsters. And monsters do not deserve redemption. They deserve only to exist. And to try, however futilely, to make the best of a terrible fate.

It is a bleak outlook, I admit. But it is the truth, as I see it. And I have lived long enough to know that truth is often far more unsettling than illusion.

(A shadow crosses Lestat’s face, a darkness that momentarily eclipses his usual flamboyance. He looks away, as if the memory is a painful one. When he speaks, his voice is softer, more vulnerable than I’ve heard it before.)

Motivation… a curious word. It implies a conscious choice, a deliberate decision. But it wasn’t like that, not at all. It wasn’t a desire for power, or immortality, or even the thrill of the hunt that drove me to embrace the darkness. It was… desperation.

I was suffocating. Trapped in a life that felt utterly meaningless. My father’s expectations, the rigid social constraints, the stifling provincialism of Auvergne… it was all crushing me. I yearned for something *more*. Something beyond the mundane. Something… extraordinary.

I sought out danger, excitement, anything that could jolt me out of my apathy. I indulged in reckless behavior, flirted with scandal, and pushed the boundaries of acceptable society. But it wasn’t enough. The emptiness remained.

And then I met Nicolas. A creature of the night, shrouded in mystery and allure. He offered me a glimpse into a world beyond my wildest imaginings. A world of power, of beauty, of endless possibilities.

(He pauses, a flicker of regret in his eyes.)

I didn’t understand the consequences, not fully. I didn’t realize the price I would have to pay. I was blinded by the promise of escape, by the allure of the forbidden. I saw it as a liberation, a transcendence. A way to finally become… *myself*.

It was foolish, reckless, and utterly naive. But I was young, and desperate, and I craved something – anything – to fill the void within me.

So, I allowed Nicolas to transform me. To bestow upon me the curse – or the gift, depending on your perspective – of immortality. And in that moment, my life changed forever.

(He looks back at me, his eyes filled with a complex mixture of pain and defiance.)

Was it the right decision? I still grapple with that question, even after centuries. But I cannot deny that it was a defining one. It was the moment I ceased to be Lestat Lioncourt, the nobleman, and became Lestat de Lioncourt, the vampire. And in a strange, twisted way, it was the moment I finally began to live. Though, perhaps, “live” is not the appropriate word. Perhaps “exist” is more accurate. But even existence, when lived on the edge of darkness, can be… exhilarating.

(The air around Lestat seems to chill, the flamboyant energy momentarily extinguished. His eyes narrow, and a dangerous stillness descends upon him. The question has clearly struck a raw nerve.)

Akasha… that ancient, arrogant, *deluded* queen. Her decision… it was not merely a mistake, it was an act of ultimate hubris. A testament to the corrosive power of immortality and isolation.

To believe that she, and she alone, possessed the right to determine the fate of our kind… to deem us unworthy of existence… it was an insult beyond measure. And to choose *me* as her sole companion, her chosen heir… that was the most infuriating part of all.

She saw me as a reflection of herself – a rebellious spirit, a creature of passion and power. She believed I would understand her vision, her desire to cleanse the world of what she perceived as a parasitic blight. She was tragically mistaken.

I do not deny that the vampire existence is fraught with peril. That we are predators, capable of great cruelty. But we are also capable of beauty, of art, of love. We are complex creatures, with a rich and diverse history. To extinguish that history, to erase our existence… it was an act of unimaginable barbarity.

(He clenches his fist, his voice laced with barely suppressed rage.)

And her reasoning… to return the world to a state of “purity,” to rule alongside a mortal king… it was the fantasy of a madwoman. A desperate attempt to reclaim a lost glory. She had become disconnected from reality, lost in the echoes of her own ancient power.

I fought her, of course. I rallied the remaining vampires, knowing full well that our chances were slim. But I could not allow her to succeed. I could not stand by and watch as our kind was wiped from existence.

The battle was… catastrophic. The world trembled. The skies burned. And in the end, it was I who was forced to destroy her. To end her reign of terror.

(He sighs, a weary sound that seems to carry the weight of centuries.)

It was a necessary evil, but it left a scar on my soul. I carry the burden of her destruction, the responsibility for the lives lost. And I will never forgive her for forcing me to make that choice.

Akasha’s decision was not born of wisdom or compassion. It was born of arrogance and despair. And it serves as a stark reminder of the dangers of unchecked power and the importance of preserving the diversity of life, even in its darkest forms. It was a lesson I will never forget. And one that I will strive to ensure is never repeated.

(Lestat throws his head back and laughs, a booming, unrestrained sound that fills the space. It’s a laugh of pure, unadulterated delight.)

Ah, the rock star years! A glorious, decadent blur of screaming fans, flashing lights, and… well, let’s just say a considerable amount of excess. You ask how I *feel* about it? I revel in it! It was, perhaps, my most audacious performance yet.

To take the darkness, the ancient power of my existence, and translate it into something… palatable for the masses. To become a cultural phenomenon, a symbol of rebellion and freedom. It was a stroke of genius, if I do say so myself.

Some of my… more traditional brethren disapproved, of course. They saw it as a vulgar display, a betrayal of our kind. They believed we should remain hidden in the shadows, manipulating events from behind the scenes. But I have never been one for subtlety. I prefer to be seen. To be heard. To be *felt*.

And the public persona? It was a carefully constructed illusion, naturally. A heightened version of myself, amplified for maximum impact. The brooding romantic, the rebellious outsider, the enigmatic artist. It was all a performance, a role I played to perfection.

(He pauses, a mischievous glint in his eye.)

But it wasn’t entirely a fabrication. There was a core of truth to it. I *am* rebellious. I *am* passionate. And I *do* crave attention. I simply chose to express those qualities in a way that would resonate with the modern world.

The music… it was a conduit for my emotions, a way to channel the centuries of experience and longing that I carry within me. It was a cry for connection, a plea for understanding, a celebration of life – and death.

And the fans? They were… intoxicating. Their adoration, their energy, their willingness to embrace the darkness. It was a validation of everything I had become.

(He sighs, a hint of nostalgia in his voice.)

It couldn’t last, of course. Nothing ever does. The world grew tired of my theatrics. The novelty wore off. And I, myself, grew restless. But the memories remain. The music remains. And the legend of Lestat de Lioncourt, the rock star vampire, continues to endure.

It was a chapter in my long and extraordinary life. A chapter I look back on with a great deal of fondness… and a touch of self-satisfaction. After all, how many vampires can claim to have topped the Billboard charts?

(Lestat throws his head back and *roars* with laughter, a sound that seems to shake the very foundations of the room. It’s a long, unrestrained laugh, laced with both amusement and a touch of defiance.)

The “Brat Prince”? *That* is what they call me? Oh, the mortals and their… reductive labels. It’s almost endearing. And utterly, utterly inaccurate.

Let them call me what they will. “Brat Prince,” “Rebel,” “The Rockstar Vampire” – it matters little. They are simply attempting to categorize something that defies categorization. They are trying to understand a creature who refuses to be understood.

The truth is, I never *asked* for a role. I never sought to be a leader, a figurehead, or a symbol of anything. I simply… *am*. I exist. And I do what I want. If that happens to ruffle a few feathers in the ancient, stagnant world of vampire politics, then so be it.

(He leans forward, his voice dropping to a low, dangerous whisper.)

Those old vampires, with their rigid rules and their archaic traditions… they are terrified of me. They see me as a threat to their power, to their control. And they are right to be. I represent everything they despise: individuality, passion, a refusal to conform.

They accuse me of being reckless, of being irresponsible, of endangering our kind. And perhaps they are not entirely wrong. But I believe that sometimes, a little bit of chaos is necessary. Sometimes, you have to break the rules in order to create something new.

I awakened Akasha, yes. A decision that many consider to be a catastrophic mistake. But I did it because I was *curious*. Because I wanted to understand the origins of our kind. Because I was tired of living in the shadows.

(He pauses, a flicker of something akin to regret in his eyes.)

The consequences were… devastating. But I do not regret my actions. I simply regret the suffering that they caused. And I have learned from my mistakes.

So, let them call me the “Brat Prince” if they wish. It is a small price to pay for the freedom to be myself. And I assure you, I will continue to be myself, regardless of what anyone thinks. I will continue to challenge the status quo, to push the boundaries, to explore the limits of my own power.

Because that, my dear, is what I was created to do. And I will not be silenced. I will not be contained. I am Lestat de Lioncourt, and I will always be a force to be reckoned with. Even if I am a “brat” while doing it.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a flicker of annoyance crossing his features. He paces slowly, his movements fluid and predatory.)

Ah, yes. The… *interpretations*. The mortal attempts to capture the essence of Lestat de Lioncourt within the confines of their limited imaginations. It is… a mixed blessing, to say the least.

Initially, I was… amused. To see my life, my experiences, transformed into a source of entertainment for the masses. It was a rather flattering, if somewhat inaccurate, portrayal. Though, the early accounts were… pedestrian. Lacking in nuance, in depth, in *understanding*. They reduced me to a caricature, a gothic romance hero. A pale imitation of the real thing.

(He stops pacing and fixes me with a piercing gaze.)

However, some of the later adaptations… they were more insightful. They captured a glimmer of the complexity, the contradictions, the *torment* that lies beneath the surface. They dared to explore the darker aspects of my nature, the moral ambiguities of my existence. And for that, I am… grudgingly appreciative.

But let us be clear. None of them have truly captured the *truth* of Lestat de Lioncourt. They are merely shadows, echoes of a life that is far more vast, far more intricate, than any mortal mind can comprehend. They are… approximations.

And the liberties they take! The alterations, the embellishments, the outright fabrications! It is… infuriating. They invent relationships, they distort events, they ascribe motives that are entirely foreign to me. They claim to know my thoughts, my feelings, my desires. As if they could possibly understand the mind of an immortal.

(He lets out a frustrated sigh.)

Still, I suppose it is inevitable. Mortals have a tendency to project their own fantasies onto those who are different, those who are powerful, those who are… *other*. And my life, with its blend of darkness and beauty, its tragedy and triumph, is a particularly fertile ground for such projections.

So, I tolerate it. I observe it with a detached amusement. And I remind myself that, ultimately, it is just a story. A fictionalized account of a life that is far more real, far more complex, than anything they could ever create.

But if any of those authors or filmmakers are listening… I have a few suggestions for improving their work. And I assure you, they would be well advised to heed my advice. It is, after all, *my* life they are portraying. And I have a rather strong opinion on how it should be told.

(Lestat’s expression darkens, a shadow passing over his features. He seems… conflicted. The flamboyant arrogance is still present, but it’s tempered by a weariness that betrays his age.)
